Cedric thanks for the reply.

>  > I have a JUnit (3.8.1) test (in eclipse =
3.1) that attemps to access a
>  > class for of statics:
>  >
>  > public f=
inal class SpecifiersHelpers {
>  >         public static final String DISP=
LAY_NAME =3D "A nice name";
>  >         public static final ErrorState ERR=
OR_STATE =3D new
>  > ErrorState("foo", null);
>  > ....
>  > }
>  >
>  > A=
s long as I only attempt to access primitive types I'm ok. But as
>  > soon=
 as I attempt to access ERROR_STATE or any other object from
>  > Specifier=
sHelpers, I get an NoClassDefError. From a little googling I
>  > can tell =
that this is a class loading problem - but beyond that I
>  > don't underst=
and. The obvious workaround is just to avoid the use of
>  > statics in thi=
s situation. However, I want to understand what's going
>  > on and how I c=
an safely use statics. BTW I'm using statics here to
>  > create a number o=
f commonly defined elements.
>
>
>  Probably one of these two things is hap=
pening:
>
>  - ErrorState is not in your classpath at runtime

That makes s=
ense except if I remove the static from ErrorState and
just use it as an in=
stance variable everything works. So there is
something about creating Erro=
rState as a static that happens before
the class is loaded.

>  - If it is,=
 its constructor is throwing an exception

Its a very simple constructor - =
just assign a pair of local variables
- no exceptions to be thrown.

Mark
